title: Ticket #5781: add caching of script output to config include command
description:
It is a common use pattern to have a config file include the output of a command, but to want to capture that output to a file after the first run and then use the resulting file for subsequent parsing of the config. This is especially important if only one process can safely run the command at the same time.

It is possible to work around this by using a combination of config if statements and temporary config variables, like this. 

example condor_config
REQUIRE_LOCAL_CONFIG_FILE = false
LOCAL_CONFIG_FILE = $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.config, $(LOCAL_DIR)/condor_config.local

example condor_config.local
if ! defined STUFF
  # stuff.pl writes "STUFF=1" to stdout and to $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.config
  include command : perl $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.pl
endif

But this mechanism is a bit hard to use, especially for RPM users. It would be better to have a first-class mechanism to declare that config files do not have to exist and to have config write the output of a script to a file and then use the file.

To do this two new keywords will be added to the include : statements in config (and submit) files: into and ifexist 

include [ifexist] command [into <cache-file>] : <cmdline>
include [ifexist] [into <cache-file>] : <cmdline> |
include [ifexist] : <file>

The into keyword must be followed by the full pathname of a file to write the output of the script into, If that file exists, it will be read and the script will not be executed. If that file does not exist, the output of the script will be written into it and then it will be read. If the script produces no output, a zero length file will be created. If the script returns a non-zero error code, configuration will abort and the cache file will not be created unless the ifexist keyword is also specified.

Also, two new keywords will make it possible to deal with script errors in a more deterministic way. 

error : error message
warning : warning message

So the above example would become 

any config file
# stuff.pl writes "STUFF=1" to stdout
include into $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.config : perl $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.pl
if ! defined stuff
  error : stuff is needed!
endif

It should be noted that the automatic configuration variables $(IsMaster) and $(CondorIsAdmin) can be used to help insure that the cache file is written only by a rootly daemon if that is needed, something like this 

any config file
if $(IsMaster)
   include into $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.config : perl $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.pl
   if ! defined stuff
      error : there must be stuff!
   endif
else
   include ifexist : $(LOCAL_DIR)/stuff.config
endif

In the future, it might be good to have a way to pass an argument to condor_reconfig to request that all scripts be run even if the cache files exist.

2016-Jul-10 12:45:40 by johnkn:
With caching of script output a first-class config feature, condor_urlfetch should be changed so that it can optionally NOT write a cache file and have the config system deal with the cache. As a side note, it would also be good if condor_urlfetch could fetch (and unpack?) archives.

Also add documentation of "include command" -- probably put all of this into section 3.3.1.6 Including Configuration from Elsewhere.

Also document "error" and "warning"...
